A reactor is operating at 3,400 MW thermal power. The core linear power density limit is 12.2 kW/ft. Given:  The reactor core contains 198 fuel assemblies.  Each fuel assembly contains 262 fuel rods, each with an active length of 12 feet.  The highest total peaking factors measured in the core are as follows: Location A: 2.5 Location B: 2.4 Location C: 2.3 Location D: 2.2 Which one of the following describes the operating conditions in the core relative to the linear power density limit? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: All locations in the core are operating below the linear power density limit.
choices.B: Location A has exceeded the linear power density limit while locations B, C, and D are operating below the limit.
choices.C: Locations A and B have exceeded the linear power density limit while locations C and D are operating below the limit.
choices.D: Locations A, B, and C have exceeded the linear power density limit while location D is operating below the limit. -920- PWR Test Items

stem: During normal operation, fuel cladding integrity is ensured by...
Maximum fuel cladding integrity is maintained by... NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: always operating below 110 percent of reactor coolant system design pressure.
choices.B: actuation of the reactor protection system upon a reactor accident.
choices.C: ensuring that actual heat flux is always less than critical heat flux.
choices.D: ensuring operation above the critical heat flux during all operating conditions. -923- PWR Test Items

stem: Peaking (or hot channel) factors are used to establish a maximum reactor power level such that fuel cladding temperature is limited to prevent __________ of the fuel cladding during most analyzed transients and abnormal conditions. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: excessive mechanical interaction -924- PWR Test Items

stem: Reactor thermal limits are established to...

choices.A: ensure the integrity of the reactor fuel.
choices.B: prevent exceeding reactor vessel mechanical limitations.
choices.C: minimize the coolant temperature rise across the core.

stem: Thermal limits are established to protect the reactor, and thereby protect the public during nuclear power plant operations, which include... NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.C: normal, abnormal, and postulated accident operations only.
choices.D: normal, abnormal, postulated and unpostulated accident operations. -925- PWR Test Items

stem: Which one of the following describes the basis for the 2,200°F maximum fuel cladding temperature limit? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: 2,200°F is approximately 500°F below the fuel cladding melting temperature.
choices.B: The material strength of cladding decreases rapidly at temperatures above 2,200°F.
choices.C: The rate of the cladding reaction increases significantly at temperatures above 2,200°F.
choices.D: At the normal operating pressure of the reactor vessel, a cladding temperature above 2,200°F indicates that the critical heat flux has been exceeded. -926- PWR Test Items

stem: Which one of the following describes the basis for the 2,200°F maximum fuel cladding temperature limit? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: 2,200°F is approximately 500°F below the fuel cladding melting temperature.
choices.B: The rate of the cladding reaction increases significantly above 2,200°F.
choices.C: If fuel cladding temperature reaches 2,200°F, the onset of transition boiling is imminent.
choices.D: The differential expansion between the fuel pellets and the fuel cladding becomes excessive at temperatures greater than 2,200°F. -927- PWR Test Items

stem: The pellet-to-cladding gap in fuel rod construction is designed to... NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: decrease fuel pellet densification and elongation.
choices.B: reduce fission product gas pressure buildup.
choices.D: reduce internal cladding strain. -928- PWR Test Items

Which one of the following describes the fuel-to-coolant thermal conductivity for a fuel rod at the end of a fuel cycle (EOC) when compared to the beginning of the same fuel cycle (BOC)? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: Smaller at EOC, due to fuel pellet densification.
choices.B: Smaller at EOC, due to contamination of fill gas with fission product gases.
choices.C: Larger at EOC, due to reduction in gap between the fuel pellets and cladding.
